title: Parametric oscillator
text:
A parametric oscillator is a <a href="harmonic%20oscillator%23Driven%20harmonic%20oscillators">driven harmonic oscillator</a> in which the oscillations are driven by varying some parameter of the system at some frequency, typically different from the <a href="natural%20frequency">natural frequency</a> of the oscillator. A simple example of a parametric oscillator is a child pumping a <a href="swing%20%28seat%29">playground swing</a> by periodically standing and squatting to increase the size of the swing's oscillations. The child's motions vary the <a href="moment%20of%20inertia">moment of inertia</a> of the swing as a <a href="pendulum">pendulum</a>. The "pump" motions of the child must be at twice the frequency of the swing's oscillations. Examples of parameters that may be varied are the oscillator's resonance frequency formula_1 and damping formula_2.
Parametric oscillators are used in several areas of physics. The classical <a href="varactor">varactor</a> parametric oscillator consists of a semiconductor <a href="varactor%20diode">varactor diode</a> connected to a <a href="resonant%20circuit">resonant circuit</a> or <a href="cavity%20resonator">cavity resonator</a>. It is driven by varying the diode's capacitance by applying a varying <a href="bias%20voltage">bias voltage</a>. The circuit that varies the diode's capacitance is called the "pump" or "driver". In microwave electronics, <a href="waveguide%20%28electromagnetism%29">waveguide</a>/<a href="Yttrium%20aluminum%20garnet">YAG</a>-based parametric oscillators operate in the same fashion. Another important example is the <a href="optical%20parametric%20oscillator">optical parametric oscillator</a>, which converts an input <a href="laser">laser</a> light wave into two output waves of lower frequency (formula_3).
When operated at pump levels below oscillation, the parametric oscillator can <a href="amplifier">amplify</a> a signal, forming a parametric amplifier (paramp). <a href="Varactor">Varactor</a> parametric amplifiers were developed as <a href="noise%20%28electronics%29">low-noise</a> amplifiers in the radio and microwave frequency range. The advantage of a parametric amplifier is that it has much lower noise than an amplifier based on a gain device like a <a href="transistor">transistor</a> or <a href="vacuum%20tube">vacuum tube</a>. This is because in the parametric amplifier a <a href="Electrical%20reactance">reactance</a> is varied instead of a (noise-producing) <a href="electrical%20resistance">resistance</a>. They are used in very low noise radio receivers in <a href="radio%20telescope">radio telescope</a>s and <a href="spacecraft%20communication">spacecraft communication</a> antennas.
Parametric resonance occurs in a mechanical system when a system is parametrically excited and oscillates at one of its resonant frequencies. Parametric excitation differs from forcing since the action appears as a time varying modification on a system parameter.
History.
Parametric oscillations were first noticed in mechanics. <a href="Michael%20Faraday">Michael Faraday</a> (1831) was the first to notice oscillations of one frequency being excited by forces of double the frequency, in the crispations (ruffled surface waves) observed in a wine glass excited to "sing". <a href="Franz%20Melde">Franz Melde</a> (1860) generated parametric oscillations in a string by employing a tuning fork to periodically vary the tension at twice the resonance frequency of the string. Parametric oscillation was first treated as a general phenomenon by <a href="John%20Strutt%2C%203rd%20Baron%20Rayleigh">Rayleigh</a> (1883,1887).
One of the first to apply the concept to electric circuits was <a href="George%20Francis%20FitzGerald">George Francis FitzGerald</a>, who in 1892 tried to excite oscillations in an <a href="LC%20circuit">LC circuit</a> by pumping it with a varying inductance provided by a dynamo.
 Parametric amplifiers (paramps) were first used in 1913-1915 for radio telephony from Berlin to Vienna and Moscow, and were predicted to have a useful future (<a href="Ernst%20Alexanderson">Ernst Alexanderson</a>, 1916). These early parametric amplifiers used the nonlinearity of an iron-core <a href="inductor">inductor</a>, so they could only function at low frequencies.
In 1948 <a href="Aldert%20van%20der%20Ziel">Aldert van der Ziel</a> pointed out a major advantage of the parametric amplifier: because it used a variable reactance instead of a resistance for amplification it had inherently low noise. A parametric amplifier used as the <a href="RF%20front%20end">front end</a> of a <a href="radio%20receiver">radio receiver</a> could amplify a weak signal while introducing very little noise. In 1952 Harrison Rowe at <a href="Bell%20Labs">Bell Labs</a> extended some 1934 mathematical work on pumped oscillations by Jack Manley and published the modern mathematical theory of parametric oscillations, the <a href="Manley-Rowe%20relations">Manley-Rowe relations</a>.
The <a href="varactor%20diode">varactor diode</a> invented in 1956 had a nonlinear capacitance that was usable into microwave frequencies. The varactor parametric amplifier was developed by Marion Hines in 1956 at <a href="Western%20Electric">Western Electric</a>. At the time it was invented microwaves were just being exploited, and the varactor amplifier was the first semiconductor amplifier at microwave frequencies. It was applied to low noise radio receivers in many areas, and has been widely used in <a href="radio%20telescope">radio telescope</a>s, satellite <a href="ground%20station">ground station</a>s, and long-range <a href="radar">radar</a>. It is the main type of parametric amplifier used today. Since that time parametric amplifiers have been built with other nonlinear active devices such as <a href="Josephson%20junction">Josephson junction</a>s.
The technique has been extended to optical frequencies in <a href="optical%20parametric%20oscillator">optical parametric oscillator</a>s and amplifiers which use <a href="nonlinear%20optics">nonlinear crystals</a> as the active element.
Mathematical analysis.
A parametric oscillator is a <a href="harmonic%20oscillator">harmonic oscillator</a> whose physical properties vary with time. The equation of such an oscillator is
This equation is linear in formula_5. By assumption, the parameters formula_6 and formula_2 depend only on time and do "not" depend on the state of the oscillator. In general, formula_8 and/or formula_9 are assumed to vary periodically, with the same period formula_10.
If the parameters vary at roughly "twice" the <a href="natural%20frequency">natural frequency</a> of the oscillator (defined below), the oscillator phase-locks to the parametric variation and absorbs energy at a rate proportional to the energy it already has. Without a compensating energy-loss mechanism provided by formula_2, the oscillation amplitude grows exponentially. (This phenomenon is called parametric excitation, parametric resonance or parametric pumping.) However, if the initial amplitude is zero, it will remain so; this distinguishes it from the non-parametric resonance of driven simple <a href="harmonic%20oscillator">harmonic oscillator</a>s, in which the amplitude grows linearly in time regardless of the initial state.
A familiar experience of both parametric and driven oscillation is playing on a swing. Rocking back and forth pumps the swing as a <a href="harmonic%20oscillator%23Driven%20harmonic%20oscillators">driven harmonic oscillator</a>, but once moving, the swing can also be parametrically driven by alternately standing and squatting at key points in the swing arc. This changes moment of inertia of the swing and hence the resonance frequency, and children can quickly reach large amplitudes provided that they have some amplitude to start with (e.g., get a push). Standing and squatting at rest, however, leads nowhere.

Parametric resonance.
Parametric resonance is the <a href="parameter">parametric</a>al <a href="resonance">resonance</a> <a href="phenomenon">phenomenon</a> of mechanical perturbation and <a href="oscillation">oscillation</a> at certain <a href="frequency">frequenc</a>ies (and the associated <a href="harmonic">harmonic</a>s). This effect is different from regular resonance because it exhibits the <a href="instability">instability</a> phenomenon.
Parametric resonance occurs in a mechanical system when a system is parametrically excited and oscillates at one of its resonant frequencies. Parametric resonance takes place when the external excitation frequency equals twice the natural frequency of the system. Parametric excitation differs from forcing since the action appears as a time varying modification on a system parameter. The classical example of parametric resonance is that of the vertically forced pendulum.

The Mathieu equation describes many other physical systems to a sinusoidal parametric excitation such as an LC Circuit where the capacitor plates move sinusoidally.
Parametric amplifiers.
Introduction.
A parametric amplifier is implemented as a <a href="frequency%20mixer">mixer</a>. The mixer's gain shows up in the output as amplifier gain. The input weak signal is mixed with a strong local oscillator signal, and the resultant strong output is used in the ensuing receiver stages.
Parametric amplifiers also operate by changing a parameter of the amplifier. Intuitively, this can be understood as follows, for a variable capacitor-based amplifier.

Knowing the above, if a capacitor is charged until its voltage equals the sampled voltage of an incoming weak signal, and if the capacitor's capacitance is then reduced (say, by manually moving the plates further apart), then the voltage across the capacitor will increase. In this way, the voltage of the weak signal is amplified.
If the capacitor is a <a href="varicap%20diode">varicap diode</a>, then "moving the plates" can be done simply by applying time-varying DC voltage to the varicap diode. This driving voltage usually comes from another oscillator—sometimes called a "pump".
The resulting output signal contains frequencies that are the sum and difference of the input signal (f1) and the pump signal (f2): (f1 + f2) and (f1 − f2).
A practical parametric oscillator needs the following connections: one for the "common" or "<a href="ground%20%28electrical%29">ground</a>", one to feed the pump, one to retrieve the output, and maybe a fourth one for biasing. A parametric amplifier needs a fifth port to input the signal being amplified. Since a varactor diode has only two connections, it can only be a part of an LC network with four <a href="eigenvector">eigenvector</a>s with nodes at the connections. This can be implemented as a <a href="transimpedance%20amplifier">transimpedance amplifier</a>, a <a href="traveling-wave-tube%20amplifier">traveling-wave amplifier</a> or by means of a <a href="circulator">circulator</a>.

Other relevant mathematical results.
If the parameters of any second-order linear differential equation are varied periodically, <a href="Floquet%20analysis">Floquet analysis</a> shows that the solutions must vary either sinusoidally or exponentially.
The formula_86 equation above with periodically varying formula_28 is an example of a <a href="Hill%20differential%20equation">Hill equation</a>. If formula_28 is a simple sinusoid, the equation is called a <a href="Mathieu%20equation">Mathieu equation</a>.
